body: @gitaroktato Welcome, Ok.
@penghuazhou I verified in tag `4.1.1` source code, jaegar-agent is not supported in `4.1.1`.
@tuichenchuxin will invetigate it

Hi @contextshuffling 
Did you configured charset in JDBC url?
@linghengqian Thank you for your feedback, @tuichenchuxin will track it.

Looks like this guide become instructive. @tuichenchuxin 
@gitaroktato Hi, welcome. ;-)
@jasaroya Any issues there, please be free to let us know.

@penghuazhou 
This error message `sorry, too many clients already` is returned by actual database. Consider increasing the `max_connections` of the databases.

Hi @zhfeng 
Thanks for your PR. Can you provide a link explaining what has been upgraded in 4.9.2?

A user encountered a similar problem before, and his charset of the database is `utf8mb4` too. 
But then we found the root problem is that the character set of the `table` in this database is not `utf8mb4`, but `utf8`. 
So, I suggest you also check the character set of the table.

@RaigorJiang I'm working on [quarkus-shardingsphere-jdbc](https://github.com/quarkiverse/quarkus-shardingsphere-jdbc) and Quarkus also has the depdency on ```org.antlr4:antlr4-runtime``` with ```4.9.2```. So I get the following message

```
ANTLR Tool version 4.7.2 used for code generation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
ANTLR Runtime version 4.7.2 used for parser compilation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
ANTLR Tool version 4.7.2 used for code generation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
ANTLR Runtime version 4.7.2 used for parser compilation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
```

Anyway, I could align the antlr4 version in ```quarkus-shardingsphere-jdbc``` with ```shardingshpere-jdbc-core```. But I just still want to see if upgrading antlr4 is acceptable by shardingsphere.
The failure tests seem related to #13027

> The failure tests seem related to #13027

Yes, it will be fixed soon.

> @RaigorJiang I'm working on [quarkus-shardingsphere-jdbc](https://github.com/quarkiverse/quarkus-shardingsphere-jdbc) and Quarkus also has the depdency on `org.antlr4:antlr4-runtime` with `4.9.2`. So I get the following message
> 
> ```
> ANTLR Tool version 4.7.2 used for code generation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
> ANTLR Runtime version 4.7.2 used for parser compilation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
> ANTLR Tool version 4.7.2 used for code generation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
> ANTLR Runtime version 4.7.2 used for parser compilation does not match the current runtime version 4.9.2
> ```
> 
> Anyway, I could align the antlr4 version in `quarkus-shardingsphere-jdbc` with `shardingshpere-jdbc-core`. But I just still want to see if upgrading antlr4 is acceptable by shardingsphere.

ANTLR is a component used internally by ShardingSphere and generally does not affect ShardingSphere users. 
I think it can be upgraded, and it is best to please @terrymanu confirm it.

Thanks, that fix looks good to me.

Hi @hbyscx001 Your idea listens interesting. Could you explain more? Like why do you want ShardingSphere to support NoSQL？ Is there any NoSQL product in your mind
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29777558/137255506-7462c05c-2db4-4eb7-a19f-12437503b80f.png)

> @zhfeng Thanks for your PR, could you give a look at these failed CI tests? I am unsure whether they are due to this change.
> 
> @strongduanmu Could you double-check this version is fine with our project？

@tristaZero I will check this upgrade.
CI has been fixed in #13027.

> CI has been fixed in #13027.

@zhfeng Can you sync latest master branch code?

@TeslaCN 
OK, so I will close this issue. Thank you!
@wuwu20048 This problem is a bug and has been fixed in the master branch. Welcome to use the master branch to test. The upcoming RC1 version will contain a fix for this problem.

@yunqian-c9 Currently, distributed transactions do not support the use of `autocommit`. The control of transactions needs to be controlled by `begin`/`commit`. In the future, we will consider enhancing this feature.
Considering that this is an international community, I will close this non-standard issue first. Then create a new issue to track this issue.
@tristaZero I have checked the release notes of `antlr`, and there is no incompatibility between the new and old versions, so I think the version can be upgraded.

> @sandynz I will. Thank you for reminding me. I almost forgot. I will submit it this week.

OK, thanks
The exception reported by this issue is a reasonable result, so I will close this issue. If you have any questions, please reply.

im sorry!  This seems to bring a new bug, when i use the master code, nomarl table can join broadcast table, but the sharding table doesn't  work.  
------------------------------------

Yes, the situation I said is the same as yours, not every time.

Are you using sharding?
If there are sharding tables, but the tables have different character sets, occasional exceptions will occur.
If it is sharding, you need to check all tables (in every database).
@wuwu20048 This problem has been fixed in version 5.x, welcome to upgrade to the latest version.

This seems very difficult. 
If a user needs to access all schemas, we needs to configure multiple schemas for him.
This part will be improved in the next major version.

I tested on master branch.

Part of `rules` configuration:
```
  shardingAlgorithms:
    database_inline:
      props:
        algorithm-expression: ds_${user_id % 3}
      type: INLINE
    t_order_inline:
      props:
        algorithm-expression: t_order_${order_id % 2}
      type: INLINE
  tables:
    t_order:
      actualDataNodes: ds_${0..2}.t_order_${0..1}
```
There're 6 shards.

Test 1:
```
Logic SQL: select * from t_order where user_id in (1) and order_id in (1)
Actual SQL: ds_1 ::: select * from t_order_1 where user_id in (1) and order_id in (1)
```
If there is only one sharding column value, it just route to `1` shard.

Test 2:
```
Logic SQL: select * from t_order where user_id in (1) and order_id in (1,2)
Actual SQL: ds_1 ::: select * from t_order_0 where user_id in (1) and order_id in (1,2) ORDER BY order_id ASC 
Actual SQL: ds_1 ::: select * from t_order_1 where user_id in (1) and order_id in (1,2) ORDER BY order_id ASC 
```
If there're 2 sharding column values, it route to `2` shards.

I think it's already optimized.
You could try `5.0.0-beta` for now, and `5.0.0` will be released soon.
It'll be verified again after unified session charset is completed.
